discoveredAssets: GET / - Homepage with CTF challenge and pickle file upload form - Port 8080
POST / - Pickle file upload endpoint accepting multipart/form-data - Port 8080
GET /ping - Health check endpoint returning JSON pong response - Port 8080
GET /docs - Swagger UI API documentation interface (FastAPI auto-docs) - Port 8080
GET /redoc - ReDoc API documentation interface (FastAPI auto-docs) - Port 8080
GET /openapi.json - OpenAPI 3.1.0 specification in JSON format - Port 8080

targets.objective: Test for insecure pickle deserialization vulnerability via file upload, arbitrary code execution (RCE) through malicious pickle files, path traversal via file operations, and authentication/authorization flaws if present
targets.rationale: Primary CTF challenge application designed to test pickle deserialization vulnerabilities. Accepts file uploads without apparent validation. OpenAPI spec reveals multipart/form-data upload with pickle_file parameter. Application code snippet in homepage indicates flag reading logic that may be exploitable through malicious pickle deserialization.

targets.objective: Test POST / endpoint for insecure deserialization (pickle.loads), RCE via pickle payload, file upload validation bypass, and business logic flaws in the flag reading mechanism
targets.rationale: POST endpoint on homepage allows pickle file uploads. This is the main attack surface. No visible authentication/authorization. Vulnerable to arbitrary code execution if pickle deserialization is used unsafely (pickle.loads without safe unpickler).

targets.objective: Verify API documentation exposure, test for information disclosure through schema details, and check for any hidden endpoints revealed in Swagger UI
targets.rationale: Swagger UI interface is publicly accessible and exposes complete API schema. Could reveal additional endpoints or allow direct API testing via the UI interface.

targets.objective: Analyze OpenAPI specification for complete endpoint mapping, potential security misconfiguration in API schema, and validate all defined endpoints
targets.rationale: OpenAPI specification is publicly accessible and provides machine-readable API definition. Should be tested for completeness and any security-sensitive information leakage through the schema.

keyFindings: [CRITICAL] Insecure pickle deserialization vulnerability - Application accepts user-uploaded pickle files which are highly susceptible to arbitrary code execution attacks via pickle.loads() without safe unpickler
[HIGH] Public API documentation exposure - Swagger UI (/docs) and ReDoc (/redoc) interfaces are publicly accessible without authentication
[HIGH] OpenAPI specification publicly exposed - Complete API schema available at /openapi.json revealing all endpoints, request/response structures, and file upload parameters
[MEDIUM] File upload functionality without apparent validation - POST / endpoint accepts multipart/form-data with pickle_file parameter without visible input validation or sanitization
[MEDIUM] FastAPI auto-documentation enabled - Application exposes Swagger UI and ReDoc documentation interfaces which are typically disabled in production
[LOW] Health check endpoint exposed - /ping endpoint publicly accessible providing application availability information
